threats.title: DoS attack threat
threats.description: An attacker locks a legitimate user out of their account by performing many failed authentication attempts.
threats.mitigation:
1. Require users to authenticate using two-factor authentication (2FA) mechanisms, such as SMS codes, authenticator apps, or hardware tokens. 2FA adds an extra layer of security, mitigating the impact of password-based attacks even if credentials are compromised.
2. Integrate CAPTCHA challenges or other challenge-response mechanisms into the authentication process after multiple failed login attempts. CAPTCHA helps differentiate between human users and automated bots, reducing the effectiveness of brute force attacks.

threats.title: JWT threat
threats.description: An attacker steals the authentication token of a legitimate user and uses it to impersonate the user.
threats.mitigation:
1. Ensure that authentication tokens are encrypted during transmission and storage. Use secure encryption algorithms and protocols to prevent attackers from intercepting and decrypting tokens.
2. Implement short expiration periods for authentication tokens. By limiting the lifespan of tokens, even if an attacker manages to steal one, its usefulness will be limited in time.

threats.title: Info threat
threats.description: An attacker extract data from a database containing user account info.
threats.mitigation:
1. Encrypt sensitive data stored in the database, especially user account information such as passwords, email addresses, and personal details. Use strong encryption algorithms and ensure that encryption keys are securely managed and stored.
2.  Implement strict access controls to limit access to the database to authorized personnel only. Use role-based access control (RBAC) mechanisms to ensure that users and administrators have the minimum necessary privileges required to perform their tasks.
